Author: aec
App_description:
Automatic ordering and checkout is the simplest embodiment of the A-commerce trend. The aim of this application is always to rid the customer journey of all friction at the checkout and ordering stages. Subconsciously, if companies already carry so much data on consumers, why should they ever have to ask for confirmation/details on an action they've performed tens, hundreds or even thousands of times.
I've bought the same toilet paper for 3 years in a row, can the multi-million euro retailer I shop at pick up on that?

Author: aec
linked_microtrends: A-Commerce,Quicker Frequent Shopping,Too Much Choice/ Simplification
App_description: Automated styling is the most organic practical hemisphere of automated commerce. This previously sci-fi reserved ambition, would in theory (not for long) curate a consumer's cart whenever they need an extra hand with choosing or simply aren't interested in spending time differentiating between two products. For some, shopping for a summer wardrobe is a ritual, for others a pain. Despite it all, with select products and services, a majority of people don't necessarily value time spent in choosing - think detergent, toilet paper, toothpaste. Wouldn't it be amazing to have the "just choose the cheapest one" or "get my anything whitening and minty".

Author: aec
App_description:
Interfacing is a hot topic nowadays. Depending on the industry, a platform's ease of use (or lack thereof) can overturn entire business ventures. It is unquestionable that we veer towards a future where human-machine interfaces are more organic, aiming to eradicate learning curves.
Currently, voice control is, with little doubt, the closest we have to achieving the fluidity necessary for this - we certainly must teach someone what "Ctrl+A" is, and does anything interesting, but shouting "Hey Siri, play me the Beatles" comes second to language (and some good taste...).

Author: aec
App_description:
One of the most significant parts contributing to Privacy Protection as a whole, is the preventive avoidance of data leaks, attacks, phishing, fraud, etc... This is the first line of defense, and it should go without saying that consumers only rest assured when they trust this is taken care of. Besides, although it is hard to measure return on investment for prevention, it is certainly cheaper than the PR crises and loss of trust that happens when it fails. Every company today should stop and think if they are prioritizing encryption, VPS usage when relevant, collecting only needed data, and the myriad of other good practices that so many neglect in place of cost reduction or marketing stunts.

An equally important side to transparency is how a brand or company behaves in case of data compromise or any abnormal case of attack. For the most part, what is increasingly being adopted is full transparency, in spite of quiet diffusal. Addressing isues that were not planned for, publicly/semi-publicly, builds trust and meets a more understanding consumer base, as opposed to coming accross as deception and losing valuable client and industry loyalty.

Author: aec
App_description: Coming partly as a response to consumers' loss of confidence in the corporate world, the glassbox model is the most honest and radical stance relative to transparency and accountability - the companies adopting this model tend to openly disclose company policy (e.g. hiring practices, salary) and veer towards open-source development. When faced with a complication that could turn into a scandal/outrage, these agents announce that fact along with efforts being made to correct the wrong, instead of trying to quietly resolve the matter before it is discovered.

Author: aec
App_description:
While Flexible Workplaces is an unquestionable trending success, there is always going to be a core mass of work that gravitates around physical headquarters. There is a parallel trend turning corporate headquarters into small cities. Whether it is one of the FAANG giants or an group of smaller companies, workers rejoice when finding all amenities within walking distance from work.
Forgot your allergy meds? Take a break and visit the pharmacy. Sick of traffic? Get up early and use that time in the work gym instead. Need to restock groceries? Walk by the supermarket when you get off.

Author: jgp
App_description:
Addressing the need to belong is the oldest commercial trick in the book. People want to be a part of something and brands must be able to address that social requirement. The good news is that the digital transformation that we're living in is boosting the businesses' ability to do it.

The digital age is skyrocketing the (peer) pressure through the roof, which, for retailers, represents both an opportunity (the feeling of emergency and the fear of missing out are sales drivers) and a threat (people's increasing desire to disconnect and to subscribe to digital detox programs or lifestyles).
List of highlights: MonsterInsight's "Who's buying what?"

Author: jgp
App_description:
Brands are living inside its customers' pockets 24/7. The ability for retailers to create the feeling of emergency is, therefore, higher than it ever was. 

People want to belong and to feel unique and businesses have an unprecedented opportunity to take advantage of those (apparently) paradoxical needs.

Author: aec
App_description:
With robots and automation making more and more frequent appearances in our everyday lives, we, people, are confronted with the progressive decrease in human interaction. Despite this, at our core, we are social animals, and we like being with other people (whether we like it or not, ah!). A collateral consequence that arises is that people give authenticity and humanity higher value. Federico Marchetti said it beautifully when he predicted that "in the future there will be one label that will convey [a sense quality] to the customers - 'Made by Humans'".
Making the right choices when it comes to automation isn't always limited to efficiency and cost. Allowing the human touch to permeate your products and services where it matters most, can be a powerful loyalty driver, justifying and even contradicting RPAs or seamlessness.
